Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: My phone buzzed insistently in my pocket as I scanned the pool, the sun glinting off the water. I knew it was my team’s group chat—waiting for my response so they could move forward with the project. I’d promised to clarify a key point before noon, and it was already 11:45. But just as I reached for my phone, I caught sight of a group of teenagers at the deep end, laughing and edging dangerously close to the “No Diving” signs. My supervisor had drilled it into us: safety first, always intervene before an accident happens. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me. If I didn’t respond to my colleagues, I’d hold everyone up and risk their frustration. But if I turned my attention to my phone, even for a minute, someone could get hurt. My heart pounded as I stood at the edge, torn between the urgent ping of my work life and the immediate responsibility of keeping everyone safe.
